text:
Hey, all! I recently read <https://foundationinc.co/lab/gongs-linkedin-strategy|this article> about Gong’s LinkedIn strategy. I was super interested in the fact that they drive organic traffic from their blog to follow them on LinkedIn (instead of, for example, to subscribe to a blog newsletter). Has anyone else tried this?

I’m mulling it over but am concerned about building a community on LinkedIn, where it feels I have less control due to algorithms, any changes LI decides to implement on the channel, etc. versus a blog subscription where I have complete control of the content people will be sent and possibly engage with. Right now, my content team has has goals for blog subscriptions and my social manager has goals around LinkedIn followers. I’m willing to change our goals depending on the strategy we take, though, so that we’re aligned across the team. Would love to hear your thoughts!

attachments.title: Gong’s LinkedIn Strategy For Breaking Through Social Media Noise
attachments.text: Gong, crushes it on LinkedIn! From scroll-stopping posts to unified employee profiles, we’re breaking down the four key aspects of Gong’s LinkedIn strategy.
attachments.fallback: Foundation Marketing: Gong’s LinkedIn Strategy For Breaking Through Social Media Noise

elements.text: Hey, all! I recently read
this article

about Gong’s LinkedIn strategy. I was super interested in the fact that they drive organic traffic from their blog to follow them on LinkedIn (instead of, for example, to subscribe to a blog newsletter). Has anyone else tried this?

I’m mulling it over but am concerned about building a community on LinkedIn, where it feels I have less control due to algorithms, any changes LI decides to implement on the channel, etc. versus a blog subscription where I have complete control of the content people will be sent and possibly engage with. Right now, my content team has has goals for blog subscriptions and my social manager has goals around LinkedIn followers. I’m willing to change our goals depending on the strategy we take, though, so that we’re aligned across the team. Would love to hear your thoughts!

text:
I've read the same article and had the same feeling.

I think it's takes a conscious effort to both drive people to LinkedIn and another effort to get people engaged.

I think better focus is finding the _right_ platform for your audience.

Gong is a sales tool so naturally there's lots of sales people following them on LinkedIn.

text: <@UJJFDTN8G> Totally. Great point about thinking in terms of the effort it takes not only to drive people to a certain place but then also keep them engaged. Ultimately that’s what I was feeling but couldn’t figure out how to verbalize it.

elements.text: Totally. Great point about thinking in terms of the effort it takes not only to drive people to a certain place but then also keep them engaged. Ultimately that’s what I was feeling but couldn’t figure out how to verbalize it.

text:
*Question for my fellow freelance writers / guest contributors in the group*: (if you don't have access to GA data), how do you track the performance of the blogs/content you produce?

For context, I've recently started offering content writing services and have now got a fair amount of guest contributions and ghost writing under my belt, but obtaining on-going feedback/performance metrics from various clients is a bit of a chore. There must be a way I can keep tabs on things without needing to check in with each of them each month! :thinking_face:

What (ideally free) tools and/or processes do others have/use?

elements.text: Question for my fellow freelance writers / guest contributors in the group

: (if you don't have access to GA data), how do you track the performance of the blogs/content you produce?

There must be a way I can keep tabs on things without needing to check in with each of them each month!
What (ideally free) tools and/or processes do others have/use?

text:
:wave::skin-tone-4: Hey folx! Do you have a preferred format for lead magnets (gated)? :magnet: Before I joined, the company I work at (B2B SaaS, HR tech) used to make lead magnet (templates, calculators, lists) available via Google Docs, but I’m not so keen on the idea. What do you usually go with?

I’m thinking a PDF could be more engaging in terms of design and branding — this, for instance, would be a list of best-practice questions for HR teams to use for a specific HR process.

:scales: Trying to weigh pros and cons, would love to hear your thoughts and experiences. Thanks.

elements.text: Hey folx! Do you have a preferred format for lead magnets (gated)?

Before I joined, the company I work at (B2B SaaS, HR tech) used to make lead magnet (templates, calculators, lists) available via Google Docs, but I’m not so keen on the idea. What do you usually go with?

I’m thinking a PDF could be more engaging in terms of design and branding — this, for instance, would be a list of best-practice questions for HR teams to use for a specific HR process.
Trying to weigh pros and cons, would love to hear your thoughts and experiences. Thanks.

text: <@U01616TECAJ> we’ve done both - Google Docs are great if it’s a public link, branded well, and it’s really a growth hack such as a fill-in template, google sheet of valuable data, swipe file, etc. If set up appropriately with a marketing automation system and GA, you could just track button clicks in terms of conversions. For our ebooks and videos, we do pdfs for ebooks mostly and just started to explore turnstiles on our videos. We’ve had a lot of luck with pdfs in the last 3 years.

elements.text: we’ve done both - Google Docs are great if it’s a public link, branded well, and it’s really a growth hack such as a fill-in template, google sheet of valuable data, swipe file, etc. If set up appropriately with a marketing automation system and GA, you could just track button clicks in terms of conversions. For our ebooks and videos, we do pdfs for ebooks mostly and just started to explore turnstiles on our videos. We’ve had a lot of luck with pdfs in the last 3 years.

text: I also work in HR tech! I think that HR peeps are pretty busy and any way to make ideas simple to use in their everyday life is great. PDFs are great, but they can be pretty clunky. If you want it to be something they read and digest a PDF is great. If you want it to be something they continually go back to and use, I think a Google Doc or Sheet is perfect because it’s low lift for them and they don’t have to download anything.

text: Depending on the type of content, Google Docs can be amazing. I get tired of things like templates or worksheets via PDF that make it hard to actually use. I'm not gonna print it out, copying and pasting things out is hard, etc. So for that stuff I love Google Docs for its easy duplicate feature. But for things that are solely read, I can see PDFs still being best.
